clinical_study.brief_title: A Single-center Pilot Study Evaluating the Immediate Effects of Low-dose Acetazolamide on Respiratory Control in Subjects With Treatment Emergent Sleep Disordered Breathing
clinical_study.official_title: A Single-center Pilot Study Evaluating the Immediate Effects of Low-dose Acetazolamide on Respiratory Control in Subjects With Treatment Emergent Sleep Disordered Breathing

lead_sponsor.agency: New York University School of Medicine

clinical_study.source: New York University School of Medicine

brief_summary.textblock: This is a single center pilot study evaluating the immediate effects of low-dose acetazolamide on respiratory control in subjects with treatment emergent sleep disordered breathing. The purpose of this study is to assess the immediate effect one-time low-dose acetazolamide on sleep breathing in (Treatment Emergent Sleep Disordered Breathing) TE-CSA subjects compared to subjects' baseline evaluation without acetazolamide. Investigators will also try to determine the immediate effect of one-time low-dose acetazolamide on subjects' resting ventilation and ventilatory response slope compared to subjects' baseline evaluation without acetazolamide.

primary_outcome.measure: Severity of Obstructive Sleep Apnea before and after acetazolamide administration using Laboratory Nocturnal Polysomnography
Total lung capacity before and after acetazolamide administration

secondary_outcome.measure: Gas composition with and without acetazolamide using Resting Ventilation Study (RVS)
Measure of ventilatory response to carbon dioxide (CO2) without and with acetazolamide

arm_group.description: Baseline evaluation of subjects without acetazolamide administration Follow up evaluation of subjects one hour after acetazolamide administration

intervention.description: Two single dose administrations of acetazolamide (once before daytime testing, and once before nighttime testing)

Exclusion Criteria:
- Hypersensitivity to acetazolamide or other sulfonamides
- Intake of carbonic anhydrase inhibitors within the last 72 hours
- Intake of medication that influences breathing, sleep, arousal or muscle physiology
- Cheyne-Stokes respiration
- Heart failure
- Renal failure
- Liver failure
- Chronic hypercapnea
- Hyponatremia
- Hypokalemia
- Pregnancy
- Breastfeeding mothers
- Active drug/alcohol dependence or abuse history
